Author: ed
Content: Just a thought: do the winners in each category bubble up to the top? It'd be cool to try and "challenge the #1 spot" with your own video.

Author: rms
Content: Well, that's slightly depressing...   it's reflective of the fundamental existential angst of humanity, we're just not made to be happy.

Author: jkush
Content: I disagree with this. You'll get so much more respect if you spend time making everything you do look easy. \n

Content: I just read about http://madkast.com">MadKast on TechCrunch..you should definitely look at that to put a "Share this" widget! :) It's beautiful.

Author: ed
Content: Eh, wait until traffic builds a bit before you clean up your act. Porn often makes for great seed content, so long as you don't let it erode your brand.

Author: queensnake
Title: Self-service economy arrives slowly, but potential barely scratched

Author: brianmckenzie
Content:
Why not let us see who has upvoted/downvoted our comments? It's frustrating when someone downvotes without explanation, especially if it's not an obviously stupid comment.

But all posters are not created equal - what if we could consider the source? If some guy with -27 karma downvotes my comment I could care less. If it's someone like Paul Buchheit, on the other hand, I have to consider the possibility that my comment was really stupid.

Author: amichail
Title: Did anyone try pay per non-click advertising?  Would that result in better targeting by advertisers?

Author: drm237
Title: Web Design Legal Horrors
Content: Few aspects of marketing are as crucial to a company's identity than its website.  And fewer marketing vehicles can become as much of a money pit and time suck as . . . a website.  It's a never-ending process of evolution, a frustrating "work in progress."

Author: extantproject
Content: Is founding a startup looked on by non-founders as something that takes a special type of person (a "smart" person, for example) when really it's just plain old work? Physics seemed like this huge daunting thing I'd never get my arms around, until I buckled down and got to work.

Author: Alex3917
Content: It'll be interesting to see if this change would affect the content on Reddit at all. Normally if you want to ride the aggregation train the ideal strategy is to wait until you hit the top of news.yc before submitting to Reddit, and then wait until you make the front page of Reddit before submitting to Digg. If good stories start hitting the #1 spot on this site during nights or on the weekends, it could potentially have some interesting ripple effects further up the chain. \n

Author: nickb
Title: In Silicon Valley, Millionaires Who Don't Feel Rich

Author: mark-t
Content:
> Viewing and not upvoting something is like half a downvote anyway.

This statement depends a lot on your habits. I open up 5-10 links at a time and then read through them all. I rarely remember to go back and upvote, and I reserve that for _really_ good articles, anyway. And of course you can't say anything about comments, since there's no telling whether somebody even reads all the comments when he opens a page with comments on it.

Author: nickb
Title: The Lisp Before the End of My Lifetime

Author: mark-t
Content:
I had the same feelings about this being old news. Also, it doesn't actually tell me anything useful.

I don't think having the problem solved in Erlang and functional languages is even close to enough, though. No offense, but there just aren't a lot of people using them. I think something like http://threadingbuildingblocks.org/ (Intel's open source C++ threading building blocks library) would be more along the lines of a real solution.

Author: augy
Content:
My takeaways

Starting is the hardest part.

Nothing succeeds like a working demo, so find a galvanizing event =YC DEMO DAY= that forces you to get a prototype built. Otherwise you will think about it to much.

There are customers that everyone else will follow zero in on them.

Excel threw other peoples resources. \n
